MESSAGE FROM THE OFFICER ADMINISTERING THE GOVERNMENT
(Assent to Bills passed)

    (ii) Central Provident Fund (Amendment) Bill;

Column: 2023

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TRANSFER OF CHRISTMAS ISLAND TO AUSTRALIA


    1. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Chief Minister whether he will make a statement regarding the transfer of Christmas Island to Australia.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat (for the Chief Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Christmas Island referred to lies in the Indian Ocean some 800 miles to

Column: 2024

the south of Singapore. This island does not belong to Singapore. The Singapore Government was notified of the decision of the United Kingdom Government to effect the transfer, and accordingly noted the position.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, does Christmas island not come under the definition of the "islands of Singapore" and is it not a fact that it has been administered by the Singapore Government?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, for administrative reasons, Christmas island was transferred to the administration of Singapore in 1900, but I should like to draw the attention of the Member for Serangoon to the fact that Christmas Island is outside the present constitution, having been excluded from the Rendel Constitution Commission's Report. The hon. Member will no doubt be aware that Members of the former Progressive Party were represented on this Commission and were signatories to that Report.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, this island is under the jurisdiction of Singapore, and giving it away to another country is, in fact, ceding away part of the territory. Is that not so, Sir?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have said just now, this island does not belong to Singapore, it belongs to the United Kingdom Government.

Column: 2024

CIVILIAN EMPLOYEES IN ARMED SERVICES
(Steps to set up tripartite committee to deal with employment problem)


    2. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Chief Minister what steps are being taken to set up the tripartite committee to deal with the employment problem affecting the civilian employees in the Armed Services; and whether the Government has adopted or will adopt measures to assist workers who have already been retrenched or will be retrenched in the immediate future.

Column: 2025



    Inche Abdul Hamid (for the Chief Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, before he left for Europe last month the Chief Minister made it known that he would, while in London, take up with the United Kingdom Government the question of the early setting up of the Tripartite Consultative Committee which was agreed upon when he was there in March and April 1957. As these are matters being personally handled by the Chief Minister, a full reply to the first part of the question must await his return.

    With regard to the second part of the question, the Government Employment Exchange has done and will do everything possible to assist the retrenched workers. Lists of their occupations have been sent to 29 employers who have been asked if they can offer any vacancies which would be suitable. The Exchange is awaiting the results. The same assistance will be given to other employees of the Armed Services if they should be retrenched in the immediate future.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Government name a date when this tripartite committee will be set up? The Government, I think, should be informed on that.

    On the second question of aid to those workers who have been retrenched or will be retrenched, can the Government adopt a more concrete form than the general form of registration of all people who are unemployed?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, to the first part of the supplementary question, I am afraid I have nothing further to add.

Column: 2026



    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Shame.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: To the second part of the question, I should say this: that Government departments have been supplied with the lists of occupations and asked to see whether they have any suitable vacancies.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Can the Government inform this House, Sir, whether there are vacancies open for the people who have been retrenched?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, we are in no position to make any definite statement regarding that.

Column: 2026

LEAVE OF ABSENCE FROM SINGAPORE OF MINISTERS
(Cost to Colony)


    3. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Minister whether he will state the number of days' leave of absence from Singapore granted, individually and collectively, to Ministers, other than ex-officio Ministers, from 2nd April, 1955, to 30th June, 1957, and the cost to the Colony in travelling and other expenses which such leave of absence has involved.

    Inche Abdul Hamid (for the Chief Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, as the information sought involves columns of figures and is of some length. I will circulate the information requested by the hon. Member for Tanglin in the Official Report.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Sir, I think this is a matter of importance to the people of Singapore and we should be informed now.

    Following is the information:

FIRE IN CECIL STREET
(Number affected and relief granted)


    4. Mr R. Jumabhoy asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare-

    (a) how many persons were affected by the recent fire in Cecil Street;

    (b) how many of them have been given alternative accommodation and where;

    (c) how many of them are awaiting accommodation, and when will they be given accommodation; and

    (d) what kind of relief has been given to the victims, and on what dates.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee (for the Minister for Labour and Welfare): To question (a) Sir, 292 persons.

    (b) Accommodation at Bushey Park and Nantina Homes offered, but the victims declined the offer and preferred to stay with relatives and friends.

    (c) 225 persons have registered with the Singapore Improvement Trust for accommodation which will be available about October 1957.

    (d) Here are the particulars:

    On 23rd May the Singapore Welfare Donation Chest gave out $4,960: the Silver Jubilee Fund $1,330.

    On 25th May the Singapore Welfare Donation Chest gave out $480; the Silver Jubilee Fund $45.

    On 27th May the Blue Cross Association donated rice and household goods to the value of $2,000.

    On 8th June the Singapore Joint Relief Organisation donated $8,520.

    On 11th June the Singapore Welfare Donation Chest donated $1,990; the Silver Jubilee Fund $40; Dr Chen Su Lan Trust $500.

    On 12th June the Singapore Welfare Donation Chest donated $520: the Silver Jubilee Fund $15.

    The total is $20,800.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that he is much

Column: 2036

more accommodating in giving columns of figures than the Acting Chief Minister?

Column: 2036

VOTING RIGHTS FOR ALIENS AND DATE OF LEGISLATIVE

ASSEMBLY GENERAL ELECTIONS


    5. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Chief Secretary what steps have been or are being taken to grant citizenship or voting rights to aliens resident in Singapore in accordance with the terms of the agreement reached at the London constitutional talks in March/April this year; and whether Government has fixed a target date for the holding of the Legislative Assembly general elections.

    Mr W. A. C. Goode: Sir, good progress has been made in drafting a Citizenship Bill and consideration has already been given to the arrangements required for carrying out the registration of citizens under that legislation. The date for holding general elections to the Legislative Assembly depends on enacting this legislation, on the period for the registration of persons eligible for citizenship, and the time required for the subsequent preparation of new electoral rolls. We have also to prepare new electoral rolls in order to hold local government elections at the end of this year and the beginning of next year. So far as can be judged at present, I doubt whether it is possible to hold elections to the Legislative Assembly before August next year.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Hon. the Chief Secretary inform the House when the proposed Citizenship Bill will come before the House?

    Mr Goode: I was hoping, Sir, that we could lay the Bill for First Reading at our next sitting in July. We will do that if possible, but I think it more probable that it will be the August sitting.

Column: 2036

SALE OF ASSEMBLY PUBLICATIONS


    6. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Secretary whether he will make arrangements for the Assembly Hansard and

Column: 2037

other publications presented to this House which are not published in the Government Gazette to be made available to the public (i) by annual subscription and (ii) at rates cheaper than the existing rates.

    Mr Goode: Sir, both the size and the number of issues of Hansard and other publications vary very greatly from year to year. It is impossible, therefore, to foresee even approximately the number of copies involved, and so it is not possible to fix annual subscription rates. However, the Government Printer accepts deposits against which these publications are supplied immediately on issue to subscribers. These publications are sold at a price which barely covers the cost of the paper and other material used. A reduction in price would cause a considerable loss of revenue, and I do not consider that it would bring any corresponding increase in sales.

Column: 2037

TANJONG PAGAR BY-ELECTIONS
(Steps to exclude non bona fide voters)


    7. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Secretary whether he will take steps to prevent persons who have registered in the Tanjong Pagar Electoral Division at addresses which are not and never have been their usual place of residence from voting at the coming by-elections; and whether steps will be taken against them under paragraph (2) of Regulation 16 of the Registration of Persons Regulations, 1955.

    Mr Goode: No, Sir. The electoral roll for the coming by elections in Tanjong Pagar was certified on 15th September last year and cannot now be altered.

    As regards the possibility of prosecution under Regulation 16 of the Registration of Persons Ordinance, any information which the hon. Member can give to the police, indicating that an offence has been committed, will be investigated.

Column: 2037

MOSQUITO NUISANCE IN SERANGOON GARDEN ESTATE


    8. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands

Column: 2038

and Housing whether he is aware of the mosquito nuisance in the vicinity of the Serangoon Garden Estate, and what steps will be taken to abate such nuisance.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been informed by the Rural Board that Serangoon Garden Estate is a private housing estate and that the responsibility for maintenance of the roadside drains and other mosquito-breeding areas lies with the developers or the purchasers of lots in the housing estate until the drains are taken over by the Rural Board.

    The Board has taken over only part of the roads and drains in the estate and the Board's cleansing section has already attended to the drains in this part. Notices have been served on the developers for the proper maintenance of the drains in the remaining part of the estate. Until the roads and drains in this remaining part are also taken over, action has been taken by the Board principally in the control of malaria transmitting mosquitoes.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that mosquito-breeding also stems from lands around the estate which are mostly swamps, and what action has been taken in that direction?

    Mr M. P. D. Nair: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that there is mosquito nuisance in his own Ministry and in his own room?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware of the mosquito nuisance in my own Ministry and in my own room, but unfortunately the mosquitoes are not residents of Serangoon Garden Estate!

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Sir, does this not point to the inefficiency of the service?

Column: 2038

REDUCED RENTS FOR NEW S.I.T. FLATS


    9. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands, and Housing whether he will consider

Column: 2039

taking steps to have the proposed rents of $30/$35 per month for the new Singapore Improvement Trust flats in the Albert Street, Prinsep Street and Short Street area reduced at least to the levels of rentals of $10 to $20 per month now being paid by the residents of houses shortly to be demolished.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, the reply is no. The White Paper on housing subsidy policy gives the method of subsidising public housing which the Government is following. In the case of flats now being built under S.I.T. Programme No. 8 for rentals of $30/$35 per month, the Government is paying a rent subsidy of, say, $30/$40 on each flat each month which, in effect, means that, but for the subsidy, the rents for these flats would be somewhere in the region of $60/$75 per month.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that some private builders are offering houses which are three times the size of the present flats at about $100 per month?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Quote facts.

Column: 2039

ELECTRICITY FOR BULIM VILLAGE


    10. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether he is aware that there is a great demand by the inhabitants of Bulim Village in Chua Chu Kang for electricity; and when will electricity be supplied to them.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware of the desire of the inhabitants of Bulim Village and others for a supply of electricity to their village. Electricity supplies have not been possible in the past as there were no electricity mains in the vicinity of Bulim Village and the cost of a scheme to supply electricity to a comparatively small and distant village would be prohibitive. However, I am informed by the City Council that a scheme for supplying the R.A.F. Station at Tengah with electricity has been prepared and

Column: 2040

should be operating by the end of the year or early in 1958. When this scheme has been completed, it will be possible for the Government to request the City Council to consider a subsidiary scheme to supply a number of villages along Chua Chu Kang Road.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that a line has been laid in Chua Chu Kang Road, and that when I wrote to the City Engineer enquiring whether he could supply electricity to the households, he said, no, it was a very high tension wire?

    Mr Speaker: Hon. Members must not merely supply information. They should ask questions.

Column: 2040

DELAY IN USING NEW BUKIT TIMAH CANAL BRIDGES


    11. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing the reasons for the delay in utilising the new bridges constructed across the Bukit Timah Canal between the 5th and 7th milestones on Bukit Timah Road.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: I am informed by the Rural Board, Sir, that there has been no delay.

    Mr John Ede: Sir, will the Minister state whether it is the intention to have one-way traffic along the Bukit Timah/ Dunearn Road area when the bridges are completed?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: The answer is yes.

Column: 2040

INCREASED RENTS OF S.I.T. SHOP PREMISES
(Enquiry)


    12. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing-

    (a) how many tenants of S.I.T. shop premises in the Alexandra / Queenstown area from Redhill Road to Strathmore Avenue are being required to pay increases in rent from 1st June, 1957, and what is

Column: 2041

the average percentage increase in rent for these premises;

    (b) why these increases are being demanded after approximately one year's tenancy only; and

    (c) whether he will cause an enquiry to be made into the justification for these increases, and whether, in the meantime, he will give an assurance that these increases will be postponed.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am informed by the Singapore Improvement Trust as follows:

    (a) The number of terrace and shop premises in the Alexandra/Queenstown area which were required to pay an increase in rent was 39 out of the total number of 66 rentals reviewed by the Board of Trustees of the Singapore Improvement Trust. Of the remaining 27 rentals, there were 25 where the rents remained unaltered, and two cases of a reduction of $10 and $25 per month respectively. The average increase in rent was $25, which is equal to a percentage increase in rent of 16.7 per cent. The original rents were based by tender.

    (b) It was previously the policy of the Board of Trustees to review all new shop rentals after a minimum of twelve months' tenancy. On first letting, the true market value cannot be correctly assessed, and is therefore only an estimate. After a shopping centre has been established for at least twelve months, a clearer picture can be obtained, and an adjustment is then made either by decreasing or increasing the rentals, having regard to the past experience of the letting demand and the established market value. However, Sir, the Board at its last meeting decided that such a review should be made only after three years.

    (c) The Board has discretion to fix rents for the tenancies of shop premises and it is therefore a question for decision by the Board, but, as I have already said, the Board has now decided to review rents only after a

Column: 2042

period of three years. In this particular case, one year has now elapsed and the review will be after another two years. This is purely a matter for the Board and I do not see any necessity for an enquiry.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, am I to understand from the Minister's statement that the increases will not now be enforced?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Sir, the increases will not now be enforced, but the decreases will be enforced.

Column: 2042

POLICY ON RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN RENT AND COST OF
S.I.T. SHOP PREMISES


    13. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether he will state-

    (i) what is the policy of Government as to the relationship between rents and value or cost of construction of S.I.T. shop premises;

    (ii) the total rent being demanded from the 20 S.I.T. shop premises surrounding the Princess Margaret Market off Stratbmore Avenue with effect from 1st June, 1957; and

    (iii) the total cost of construction of these shop premises excluding the market.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: The matter of fixing rents for shop premises, Sir, is purely a matter for the Singapore Improvement Trust. I am informed by the Board, with regard to these questions, that-

    (i) There is no direct relationship between the rents fixed for shop premises and their cost of construction and other overheads, though it is unlikely that such rents would give less than an economic return on costs. They are assessed on their value as business premises by the Board with the advice of the City Assessor, taking into account locality and other such relevant factors. In the past, except for rehousing cases,

Column: 2043

it is usual for these shops to be let by tender at not less than the rents assessed.

    (ii) The total rent being demanded from the 20 S.I.T. shop premises surrounding the Princess Margaret Market off Strathmore Avenue, with effect from 1st June, was $4,335 per month. However, as the Board has agreed to defer reassessment of these rents until the businesses have been operating for three years, the total rent for the 20 houses will now be $3,830 per month.

    (iii) The total cost of construction of these shop premises, excluding the market, was $90,000. This, however, excludes the cost of roads, drains, part of the cost of sewers and the cost of land, for which a sum of approximately $60,000 must be added.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, is the Minister aware that the retail prices in the shops are higher than those in the city and that Queenstown residents are going to the city to get their domestic needs instead of buying at these shops? Is the Minister also not aware that this is due to the high rents which are paid, and will he not consider a further reduction in respect of shops other than the two already referred to?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: I am not aware, Sir.

Column: 2043

NAMES OF S.I.T. TRUSTEES AND DATES OF NOMINATION


    14. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing to state the names of the persons nominated by him or by the Governor in Council who are now serving on the Board of Trustees of the S.I.T., and the dates of such nominations.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, neither the Governor in Council nor the Minister appoints members of the Board of Trustees of the Singapore Improvement Trust, except in one case where the Governor in Council appoints the Manager. The last appointment was on the 1st of September, 1956,

Column: 2044

when Mr Fraser was appointed Chairman of the Singapore Improvement Trust.

Column: 2044

OVER-PAYMENT TO CHINESE SCHOOL TEACHERS
AND REFUND OF EXCESS


    15. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Education-

    (a) how many Chinese-school teachers were paid in error sums in excess of their correct salaries;

    (b) why such Chinese-school teachers were required to refund such excesses in one lump sum instead of by instalments;

    (c) how many of such Chinese-school teachers, as a result of such refunds, received less than $20 as their salary for the relevant month; and

    (d) whether he is aware of hardships caused to such Chinese-school teachers by reason of such refunds, and what steps he has taken or will take to alleviate such hardships.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: (a) Sir, so far only five Chinese school teachers are known to have been paid in error sums in excess of their correct salaries.

    (b) Sir, this is due to a misunderstanding by the schools that over-payments of salaries could be refunded by instalments.

    (c) Only one case has been brought to my Ministry's notice.

    (d) Yes, I am aware that some refunds could cause hardships to such teachers, and as soon as I learned of such cases, I gave immediate instructions that deductions must be made by reasonable instalments.

Column: 2044

DELAYED IMPLEMENTATION OF POLICY ON CHINESE
SCHOOLS AND PAYMENT OF SPECIAL-POST ALLOWANCES TO
PRINCIPALS


    16. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Education the reasons for the delay in implementing the policy of

Column: 2045

equal conditions of service in all Chinese schools which have accepted full aid, and when the special-post allowances to principals in such schools will be paid.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the implementation of the policy of equal conditions of service in all Chinese schools that come into the full aid scheme has not been completed as early as I had wished, partly because of shortage of staff in the Ministry, and partly because service conditions for Chinese teachers have brought in fresh problems of Chinese qualifications of which there are many, and the recognition of past services. All these present a big administrative problem and must take time to solve.

    The question of post allowances in the Chinese schools is being examined and it is hoped that this question will be settled in the very near future.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that all Parties are agreed on the policy of equality for Chinese schools and that through this delay the Chinese schools no longer believe that the Government supports this policy?

Column: 2045

REASON FOR PUBLISHING 1955 HEALTH MINISTRY REPORT
IN 1957 AND ISSUE DATE OF 1956 REPORT


    17. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Health why the report of his Ministry for 1955 was published only in May 1957; and when it is proposed to publish the report for 1956.

    Mr A. J. Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, owing to the increased expansion of the medical services and the necessity for carefully checking the volume of statistical material included in the Report, it was not possible to bring it out earlier. The Statistics Department had been put on other urgent commitments, one of which was the work relating to elections which entailed a tremendous amount of work. It was therefore not possible for the Department to work on detailed data exclusively and to submit to my Ministry the essential statistical

Column: 2046

details in time. Without such material, even textual matters could not be elaborated on adequately.

    It is not possible for me to say when the 1956 Annual Report will be published.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that these Reports inevitably become of very much less value if published a year later?

    Mr Speaker: That is a matter of opinion.

Column: 2046

AID TO "PIRATE-TAXI" DRIVERS TO OBTAIN PROPER
LICENCES


    18. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Minister for Communications and Works whether Government has taken or will take steps to assist those at present referred to as pirate-taxi drivers to obtain proper licences.

    Mr Francis Thomas: No, Sir. This is wholly a matter for the City Council. I do not propose to infringe on their autonomy.

Column: 2046

TELEPHONES FOR BULIM VILLAGE


    19. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Communications and Works whether he is aware that there is a great demand by the inhabitants of Bulim Village in Chua Chu Kang for telephones; and when will telephones be installed in that area.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Yes, Sir, I am aware of the need and of the demand for telephones in Bulim Village and indeed in the rural areas of Singapore generally. The hon. Member is, however, doubtless aware that the provision of telephone services is a matter for the Singapore Telephone Board. The Board has its plans for the progressive extension of these services and I am not in a position to answer for the Board as to when a service will be provided in any particular area for it to meet the demand of that area, if the hon. Member will approach the Chairman of the Board, I am sure he will be fully advised of the prospects of the service to which he refers and when it will be provided.

Column: 2047



    Mr Goh Tong Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, do I understand that as a Minister he has no hold on the Telephone Board?

    Mr Speaker: That is exactly what the Minister said - he has no ministerial responsibility.

Column: 2047

NEED TO WIDEN HOLLAND ROAD


    20. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Communications and Works if he is aware of the urgent need to widen Holland Road from its junction with Ulu Pandan Road to its junction with Bukit Timah Road; and what steps he proposes to take in this matter.

    Inche Abdul Hamid (for the Minister for Communications and Works): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Rural Board has already gone into this matter and has found that it is not feasible to straighten and widen this segment of Holland Road as it would necessitate the acquisition of land within fairly new Chinese cemeteries. Provision has already been made in this year's Rural Board estimate for a link road from approximately the 5¾ milestone Holland Road to join up Bukit Timah Road at the 6th milestone. This would make the widening of Holland Road unnecessary. The making-up of Coronation Road as another link road is also in train.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister not aware that even a minor widening of the stretch of Holland Road under reference would assist traffic a very great deal?

    Mr Speaker: That is a matter of opinion.

Column: 2047

DEEP-SEA FISHING LICENCES


    21. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry-

    (a) how many applications for licences for deep-sea fishing have been received;

    (b) how many licences have been granted;

    (c) what are the conditions which have to be fulfilled before a licence is granted;

Column: 2048



    (d) what is the maximum number of licences he is prepared to grant;

    (e) what expenses have been incurred by Government in the granting of licences up to a last convenient date, and what extra expenses will be incurred in the granting of more licences; and

    (f) what is the estimated increase in the country's food supplies consequent on the granting of more licences.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: (a) Eight applications for licences for deep-sea fishing were received when Government invited applications in May 1956. During 1957 four further applications have been received.

    (b) Three licences have been granted in accordance with Government's decision.

    (c) When applications were invited in May 1956, certain conditions had to be fulfilled before an application was considered. These conditions were set out in Press advertisements, and the hon. Member can refer to them in the Straits Times and the Singapore Standard of 16th and 17th April, 1956.

    1. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether he will appoint a Committee to examine the hawker problems and make recommendations thereon.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Government has decided that it would be desirable in principle to set up a Hawkers' Advisory Committee consisting of the following members : -

    (a) two nominees of the Government;

    (b) two nominees of the City Council;

    (c) two representatives of hawkers to be chosen in consultation with the appropriate hawkers associations; and

    (d) an independent Chairman, who may be a housewife.

    The Committee would advise the appropriate authorities on problems relating to hawkers, generally or specifically.

    The City Council is intimately concerned with the hawkers problem, and its views and co-operation are therefore being sought before the Committee is formally constituted.

    It is not intended that this Committee should usurp the functions of the City Council in its handling of the hawker problem, but as this problem has assumed major proportions recently, Government is of the opinion that a purely advisory body representing all parties concerned in this matter should now be established.
